Advanced Healthcare Materials published by Wiley‐VCH GmbH https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ Abstract X‐ray excited luminescence chemical imaging (XELCI) and associated sensor surfaces are designed to noninvasively study, detect, and monitor local chemistry at the surface of modified implanted medical devices during infection. Implants are coated with polymer films containing scintillators and pH indicator dyes that together generate a pH‐dependent luminescence when irradiated by X‐rays. A focused X‐ray beam provides high spatial resolution, while the pH indicator provides chemical sensitivity. A live rabbit pH‐imaging study on a scintillator‐coated implanted titanium plate evaluates the sensor performance with and without Staphylococcus aureus Imaging pH in a live rabbit at the surface of a sensor‐coated titanium plate using X‐ray excited luminescent chemical imaging (XELCI). A raster scanning X‐ray beam generates radioluminescence from a spot on the sensor, and the luminescence passes through the tissue and is collected at two wavelengths to determine local pH. Healthcare Mater. 14 25 2025 14 2501215 10.1002/adhm.202501215 PMC12477567 40739608 1 Introduction Orthopedic implants such as intramedullary nails, plates, screws, and external fixation pins are routinely used for fracture fixation. Unfortunately, ≈5% of 2 million fracture fixation devices in the US get infected, [  1 ] [  2  3 ] Staphylococcal [  4 ] Diagnosis and treatment of implant‐related infection can be challenging, and a combination of clinical, laboratory, and microbiological findings in conjunction with imaging studies is required to monitor such infection. Inexpensive hematologic tests for inflammation, such as C‐reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), can help to diagnose implant‐associated infection; [  5 ] [  6 ] Sensors at the implant surface, where the biofilm resides, would be expected to provide an earlier detection threshold and potentially the ability to monitor the infection during antibiotic treatment. Probing the local biochemistry and bacterial metabolism can also help researchers develop better biofilm‐targeting anti‐microbial therapies. In particular, low pH regions at the biofilm/substrate interface are believed to indicate persistent antibiotic‐tolerant biofilm regions (e.g., dormant bacteria with low oxygenation and poor vascular clearance of acidic byproducts, and potentially poor antibiotic delivery). Based on the pathology report, no abnormalities were observed in the cortical bone or the medullary cavity, and new bone formation was evident around the implant, indicating good biocompatibility of the implants as seen in Figure 7F,G Staphylococcus epidermidis S8 3 Conclusion The purpose of this study was to show proof of concept for XELCI imaging in live animals and to evaluate sensor performance and suitability, and to establish a protocol for future in vivo studies. The sensor‐modified orthopedic implant demonstrated promising results in terms of sensor design, calibration, mechanical integrity, biocompatibility, and in vivo testing. The sensor was found to be reversible and responded to pH changes within 5–30 min. The sensor was calibrated through tissue and demonstrated successful imaging through ≈1 cm of soft tissue in rabbit studies. In vitro biofilm formation was observed on the sensor films, with a biofilm coverage of 54% after 24 h. In vivo studies were conducted on rabbits, with the sensors implanted and inoculated with S. aureus Two levels of inoculum amounts were tested to establish a minimum concentration of inoculum required to successfully establish infection without proving to be fatal for the animal. A minimum inoculum of 5000 CFU was determined to be used for future inoculations to induce infection, as no fatality was observed. Since no bacteria was recovered from the control legs of the infected rabbits negating the concern of possible spread of infection from infected to non‐infected leg in the same animal, we can eliminate the use of a control animal (with both legs as control) for future studies and designation of one leg as non‐infected in each animal should suffice as control. The study with the vinyl sensor showed that we could image a change in absorption in vivo, although from the implant color postmortem, it was clear that we were imaging sensor leaching rather than a large pH change. For rabbits with the PEG‐coated implant (P‐R1, P‐R2, and P‐R3), no measurable leaching was observed over 10 days. There were clear signs of infection in P‐R2 and P‐R3, while by contrast, the tissue in the control rabbit (P‐R1) was completely healthy. However, we could not observe a clear pH change in the infected animals/legs. This may indicate that the pH did not fall at the implant surface, at least within the pH 3–6 range that the sensor can sense. Therefore, the PEG sensor used in this study will be optimized for increased sensitivity within the biological range of pH (pH 6.0–7.4) and used for further studies. The long‐term biocompatibility study indicated that the coated implants were well tolerated while implanted along the tibial periosteal surfaces of adult rabbits for 80 days. Most implants were partially encased in new bone formation, and there was no evidence of suppuration or inflammatory infiltrates in the sections examined microscopically. Overall, the results of this study provide a foundation for in vivo pH imaging near implanted medical devices. They provide protocols for infection, demonstrate the materials are biocompatible, and show the ability to image in vivo for long periods of time. Sensor Coated Orthopedic Implant The sensor‐coated orthopedic implant was prepared by coating a titanium plate with the two sensor layers, a bottom layer of scintillator particles (Gd 2 2 there was no fracture to simplify the model and to avoid unnecessary pain and discomfort to the animals To make a plate, titanium sheet metal, (0.020 inch thick Ti‐6Al‐4 V ELI, implant grade 6‐4 Titanium, M. Vincent & Associates, MN, USA) was cut into 18 × 6 mm plates, polished with 240 grit sand paper, rinsed with alconox detergent and water, and sonicated in acetone followed by ethanol for 15 min each. To attach the scintillator layer to the plate, silicone elastomer and curing agent (SYLGARD 184 Silicone Elastomer base and curing agent, Dow Corning, Midland, Michigan, United States) were mixed in 10:1 (w/w) ratio and ≈8.0 µm diameter Gd 2 2 The pH‐sensitive film was synthesized and placed over the scintillator layer. The pH‐sensitive film consisted of a PEG hydrogel with BCG dye (pH range 3–6) ≈200 µm thick. The hydrogel film consisted of a solution containing 79% (w/w of sol.) 700 MW polyethylene glycol diacrylate (PEGDA), 9.9% (w/w of sol.) glycerol, 9.9% (w/w of sol.) water, 0.8% (w/w of sol.) photo initiator (2,2‐dimethoxy‐2‐phenylacetophenone) and 0.4% (w/w of sol.) bromocresol green (pH‐indicating dye). This mixture was stirred on a magnetic plate for 30 min, and the resulting solution was polymerized as follows: The polymerizable hydrogel solution was drop‐coated and sandwiched between two clean coverslips and cured under UV light for 2 min. The films were immersed in water to swell and delaminate from the coverslips and washed several times before being cut into 14 × 6 mm pieces. This PEG hydrogel was glued onto the scintillator layer (cured on the titanium plates) using superglue. Sensor Calibration To measure the attenuation of the scintillator emission signal by the pH dye, the sensor (a piece of pH film covered by scintillator film), immersed in standard buffer solution, was placed on the stage of an inverted microscope (DMI 5000, Leica Microsystems, Germany) and irradiated with a focused X‐ray beam. The pH modulated emission of the scintillator film was collected by a 5X objective lens and focused on a spectrometer (DNS 300, DeltaNu, Laramie, WY, USA), equipped with a cooled CCD camera (iDUS‐420BV, Andor, South Windsor, CT, United States). Spectra were collected for each pH after immersing the pH film in the respective buffers. For sensor caibration using XELCI without tissue, the 3D printed holder containing 5 pH sensor discs (in pH buffers 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8) and a reference disc as well as a reference strip was placed on top of a 5 mm thick piece of chicken tissue wrapped in plastic and scanned from the top using XELCI. For sensor calibration through tissue, the XELCI imaging was repeated by covering the top of the sensor discs with an 11 mm‐thick slice of chicken breast tissue. From the data, calibration curves could be plotted showing peak ratio and intensity versus pH. Mechanical Integrity for Irrigation and Debridement The PEG hydrogel film was tested for simulation of high‐pressure irrigation during irrigation and debridement (I&D) by placing it under running tap water and increasing the water flow to maximum. The flow of water was determined by measuring the amount of time required to fill a 1000 mL beaker at a given flow. One leg of the animal was kept as a control (no inoculation), and one leg was infected. Surgery was performed by the Clemson University veterinarian, and all animal studies were conducted at the Clemson University Godley‐Snell Research Center after approval of the Institutional Biosafety Committee (IBC) and Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). Animal anesthesia during imaging and euthanasia at termination was also administered by the Godley‐Snell Research Center staff. Implantation and Inoculation The prepared orthopedic device was implanted in the rabbit femur. For each hind leg of the animal, a 2 cm incision was made and the implant was attached to the femur with either medical glue (cyanoacrylate), and the incision was closed with sutures. Inoculation was done during surgery after fixation of the implant on the bone. The implant and surrounding tissue were inoculated with either 500 or 5000 CFU of S. aureus S. aureus was cultured in tryptic soy broth for 18 h prior to experiments. Bacteria on implant surfaces were detached by submerging the explants in phosphate‐buffered saline (PBS) and subjecting them to an ultrasound water bath at 40 kHz for 5 min. The recovered bacteria were serially diluted and plated on tryptic soy agar for enumeration. Soft tissue from the area surrounding the implant was placed in pre‐weighed 50 mL sterile centrifuged tubes. These tubes were then weighed again to determine the weight of the recovered soft tissue. 4 mL PBS was added to each tube, and tissues were homogenized (Bio‐Gen PRO200 Homogenizer, VWR) on ice using the maximum setting for 30 s or until they appeared homogenized. They then sat on ice for 5 min to yield supernatant. The supernatant was serially diluted and plated on a tryptic soy agar plate for enumeration. Imaging After surgery, plain X‐rays were taken, under isoflurane, and a preliminary XELCI image was taken of each leg. The implant pH was imaged in vivo using our novel imaging modality, X‐ray excited luminescence chemical imaging (XELCI), at least three times per week for two weeks. The scanning process and signal processing are explained in our other publications. [  13  15  43 ] Termination and Postmortem After two weeks, rabbits were euthanized with commercial euthanasia solution, and a terminal 5 mL blood sample was obtained. Postmortem studies included retrieval of the implanted sensors, visual inspection of the implant and surrounding tissue, culturing of bacteria from the surrounding tissue, and confirming reversibility of the retrieved pH sensor films. The rabbit femurs (some with an implant attached and others without an implant) were stored in a freezer for microCT imaging and in formalin for histological examination. MicroCT (MicroCT SkyScan 1176, Bruker, MA, USA) scans were done at 35 µm resolution with a source voltage of 80 kV and current 313 µA. Long‐Term Biocompatibility Study Titanium discs cut into 5 mm diameter were used as the implants and coated with the scintillator layer prepared as described in the Experimental Section under the heading “Sensor Calibration”. Half of the implants were subsequently attached with a layer of PEG hydrogel loaded with bromocresol green indicator (as described in the Experimental Section under the heading “Mechanical Integrity for Irrigation and Debridement”) using super glue (Loctite, Henkel Corporation, CT). A droplet of the glue was spread on the PDMS, and the PEG hydrogel film was pressed onto the PDMS for ≈2 min to attach. The reference implants without the PEG sensor coating served as spectral references so that tissue effects on the spectrum could be established. To image the scintillator‐coated discs in a live rabbit, we placed the rabbit in an IVIS Lumina‐XR imaging system (Caliper Life Sciences, Hopkinton, MA, USA) along with a miniature X‐ray source (mini‐X‐ray tube, Ag target, Amptek Inc., MA, USA). The radioluminescence images were acquired in bioluminescence mode while the X‐ray was turned on, as described previously in ex vivo tissue [  44  45 ] [  22 ] The prepared reference and sensor implants were sterilized by incubation in 2% glutaraldehyde for 8 h and then rinsed with sterilized water three times and saved in sterilized PBS. Both a reference disc and a sensor disc were implanted on the tibia of each leg of two rabbits. Rabbit 1 was a complete control animal, whereas infection was introduced on the left leg of Rabbit 2.
